shredder 0.0.4
  • Reference
  • Articles

Usage

Source: vignettes/Usage.Rmd
Usage.Rmd
library(shredder)

Example

This is a basic example which shows you how to solve a common problem:

library(shredder)
library(rstan)
#> Loading required package: ggplot2
#> Loading required package: StanHeaders
#> Warning: package 'StanHeaders' was built under R version 3.5.2
#> rstan (Version 2.18.2, GitRev: 2e1f913d3ca3)
#> For execution on a local, multicore CPU with excess RAM we recommend calling
#> options(mc.cores = parallel::detectCores()).
#> To avoid recompilation of unchanged Stan programs, we recommend calling
#> rstan_options(auto_write = TRUE)
objsize <- function(x){
  sprintf(
    'Object Size: %s',
    format(object.size(x),units = 'auto')
  )
} 

excode <- '
  transformed data {
    real y[20];
    y[1] = 0.5796;  y[2] = 0.2276;   y[3]  = -0.2959; 
    y[4] = -0.3742; y[5] = 0.3885;   y[6]  = -2.1585;
    y[7] = 0.7111;  y[8] = 1.4424;   y[9]  = 2.5430; 
    y[10] = 0.3746; y[11] = 0.4773;  y[12] = 0.1803; 
    y[13] = 0.5215; y[14] = -1.6044; y[15] = -0.6703; 
    y[16] = 0.9459; y[17] = -0.382;  y[18] = 0.7619;
    y[19] = 0.1006; y[20] = -1.7461;
  }
  parameters {
    real mu;
    real<lower=0, upper=10> sigma;
    vector[2] z[3];
    real<lower=0> alpha;
  } 
  model {
    y ~ normal(mu, sigma);
    for (i in 1:3) 
      z[i] ~ normal(0, 1);
    alpha ~ exponential(2);
  } 
'
fit <- rstan::stan(model_code = excode, iter = 500, verbose = FALSE)
objsize(fit)
#> [1] "Object Size: 348.8 Kb"

fit
#> Inference for Stan model: 9eb770bb13e360b55b7f4acaf07142c1.
#> 4 chains, each with iter=500; warmup=250; thin=1; 
#> post-warmup draws per chain=250, total post-warmup draws=1000.
#> 
#>          mean se_mean   sd   2.5%    25%    50%    75%  97.5% n_eff Rhat
#> mu       0.10    0.01 0.26  -0.41  -0.08   0.10   0.28   0.62  1386    1
#> sigma    1.17    0.01 0.20   0.85   1.02   1.15   1.29   1.61  1199    1
#> z[1,1]  -0.01    0.03 1.00  -1.98  -0.69   0.00   0.66   1.88  1520    1
#> z[1,2]   0.02    0.03 0.99  -1.87  -0.67   0.02   0.67   2.03  1406    1
#> z[2,1]   0.00    0.03 1.02  -2.08  -0.64   0.01   0.69   1.91  1495    1
#> z[2,2]   0.04    0.03 0.98  -1.92  -0.65   0.09   0.73   1.87  1524    1
#> z[3,1]   0.03    0.03 1.01  -2.00  -0.62   0.02   0.72   1.99  1245    1
#> z[3,2]   0.01    0.03 1.04  -2.10  -0.68   0.00   0.72   1.97  1507    1
#> alpha    0.53    0.01 0.55   0.01   0.14   0.37   0.76   2.14  1594    1
#> lp__   -17.72    0.10 2.25 -23.11 -18.89 -17.41 -16.17 -14.31   468    1
#> 
#> Samples were drawn using NUTS(diag_e) at Tue May 14 22:59:12 2019.
#> For each parameter, n_eff is a crude measure of effective sample size,
#> and Rhat is the potential scale reduction factor on split chains (at 
#> convergence, Rhat=1).

Pars

Names

fit%>%stan_names()
#> [1] "mu"    "sigma" "z"     "alpha" "lp__"

fit%>%stan_names(expand = TRUE)
#>  [1] "mu"     "sigma"  "z[1,1]" "z[2,1]" "z[3,1]" "z[1,2]" "z[2,2]"
#>  [8] "z[3,2]" "alpha"  "lp__"

Select

fit1 <- fit%>%
  stan_select(mu)

objsize(fit1)
#> [1] "Object Size: 173.6 Kb"

fit1
#> Inference for Stan model: 9eb770bb13e360b55b7f4acaf07142c1.
#> 4 chains, each with iter=500; warmup=250; thin=1; 
#> post-warmup draws per chain=250, total post-warmup draws=1000.
#> 
#>    mean se_mean   sd  2.5%   25% 50%  75% 97.5% n_eff Rhat
#> mu  0.1    0.01 0.26 -0.41 -0.08 0.1 0.28  0.62  1386    1
#> 
#> Samples were drawn using  at Tue May 14 22:59:12 2019.
#> For each parameter, n_eff is a crude measure of effective sample size,
#> and Rhat is the potential scale reduction factor on split chains (at 
#> convergence, Rhat=1).

fit2 <- fit%>%
  stan_select(mu,sigma)

objsize(fit2)
#> [1] "Object Size: 190.6 Kb"

fit2
#> Inference for Stan model: 9eb770bb13e360b55b7f4acaf07142c1.
#> 4 chains, each with iter=500; warmup=250; thin=1;

#> For each parameter, n_eff is a crude measure of effective sample size,
#> and Rhat is the potential scale reduction factor on split chains (at 
#> convergence, Rhat=1).

fit3 <- fit%>%
  stan_select(!!!rlang::syms(c('z','alpha')))

  stan_select(stan_contains('z'))

Post-warmup samples

Subsetting post warmup samples


  fit4 <- fit%>%
    stan_slice(1:50,inc_warmup = TRUE)

  objsize(fit4)
#> [1] "Object Size: 165.6 Kb"

  fit4
#> Inference for Stan model: 9eb770bb13e360b55b7f4acaf07142c1.

#>

    stan_select(mu)%>%
    stan_slice(1:50)

Split


fit9 <- fit%>%
    stan_split(inc_warmup = TRUE)

length(fit9)
#> [1] 10

purrr::map_chr(fit9,objsize)

#> "Object Size: 154.4 Kb" "Object Size: 154.4 Kb" "Object Size: 154.4 Kb"

fit10 <- fit%>%
    stan_split(inc_warmup = FALSE)

purrr::map_chr(fit10,objsize)
#>                      1                      2                      3 
#> "Object Size: 76.2 Kb" "Object Size: 76.2 Kb" "Object Size: 76.2 Kb" 
#>                      4                      5                      6 
#> "Object Size: 76.2 Kb" "Object Size: 76.2 Kb" "Object Size: 76.2 Kb" 
#>                      7                      8                      9

#>                     10 
#> "Object Size: 76.2 Kb"

#> 
#>          mean se_mean   sd   2.5%    25%    50%    75%  97.5% n_eff Rhat
#> mu       0.07    0.02 0.29  -0.48  -0.12   0.10   0.30   0.59   144 1.00
#> sigma    1.17    0.02 0.22   0.82   1.02   1.14   1.30   1.61   148 0.99

    stan_split(ncut = 4, inc_warmup = FALSE)
